column4: Trait_description
Agriculture (horticulture) present (i.e., domesticated food plants cultivated)

column3: Agriculture and domestic animals are primary subsistence
column4: Agriculture and/or domesticated animals provide the major part of subsistence (about 75% or more)
Agricultural plots repeatedly cultivated except for periods of fallow (if they occur)
Improved techniques of planting (e.g., mounds, planting in rows, breaking of clods, plowing, fertilization)
Soil-working tools other than the digging stick (e.g., hoe, spade, rake, foot plow)
Harvesting tools other than a simple beating stick used in reaping or threshing domesticated plants (e.g., flail, sickle, rice header, winnowing tray)
Animal-drawn plow
Fertilization of land with material other than wood ashes (e.g., animal manure, night soil, green manure, compost, fresh soil or mud)
Fences built around fields or gardens to protect crops
Men do as much or more of the agricultural work as women (beyond clearing)
Drainage employed to increase the area of available agricultural land
Irrigation of agricultural land
Permanent dams or dikes to impound water for irrigation, drinking, etc.
Terracing (including the erection of barriers to reduce soil slippage)
Agricultural land reverts to kinship group (e.g., lineage, sib), chief or tribe, king or state, as personal property or for reassignment when owner abandons the land or dies without heirs

Most of the agricultural land systematically reapportioned from time to time by the village, chief, tribe, or state to insure equitable distribution and/or a high degree of cultivation, rather than for services rendered

column3: Measures to promote or maintain agricultural production
column4: Chief, king, or other official(s) takes measures to promote or maintain agricultural production (e.g., requires land to be worked efficiently and punishes failure to do so)

column3: Planting and harvesting times determined by specialists
column4: Political or religious officials or other specialists determine the time of planting and harvesting

column3: State or church provides farmers with equipment
column4: State or church provides farmers with seed or tools for agricultural purposes
State surveying of agricultural land
Surplus of food regularly accumulated over and above the annual subsistence needs of the food producers, and not consumed by them
Agricultural estates which regularly produce a sizable surplus of food for sale to urban centers
Cash crops raised entirely or largely for sale rather than for domestic consumption
Granaries erected by the government and food distributed from them by a government official

column3: Domesticated animals serve as a source of food
column4: Domesticated animals serve as a source of food (exclude the eating during famines or other unusual occasions of domesticated animals not normally used as food)
Domesticated animals used for packing
Domesticated animals used for traction
Domesticated animals used for riding

column3: Domesticated animals kept for wool or hair
column4: Domesticated animals kept for wool or hair
Selective breeding of domesticated animals
Specialized herdsmen or dairymen
Fisheries or fish ponds stocked and maintained to provide a regular supply of fish for food

column3: Settlements occupied for more than 10 years
column4: Settlements occupied for more than 10 years, on the average (but not necessarily all year around but at least 40 percent of the year)

column3: Settlements occupied for at least 50 years
column4: Settlements occupied for at least 50 years (but not necessarily all year around but at least 40 percent of the year)
Settlement(s) arranged in regular pattern(s), (e.g., long house, houses in rows or streets, houses built around a square or plaza)
Permanent communities (settled or nomadic) of about 100 or more members
Permanent communities (settled or nomadic) of about 500 or more members
Towns: nucleated settlements of 2,000 or more residents
Two or more towns
City: administrative and commercial population center of at least 10,000 residents
Two or more cities
City of 100,000 or more residents
Planned cities
Paved streets
Paved sidewalks
Paved plaza (exclude patios surrounded by house walls or exclusive to individual houses)

Civic or ceremonial structures (including men’s house) not ordinarily used as dwellings by family units (excluding structures built for specific occasions and later abandoned, dismantled, or destroyed)
Permanent cemeteries, where the graves of the interred are marked

column3: Stone monuments commemorating persons or events
column4: Stone monuments or stelae (excluding cairns of unworked stones) to mark or commemorate important persons or events (e.g., megaliths, obelisks, triumphal arches, pyramids)
Grandstands, theathers, amphitheaters, or stadiums where spectators can witness contests or performances
Formal or landscape gardens
Ornamental fountains
Aqueducts or conduits of stone or brick to supply water for domestic use
Running water piped into dwellings or public buildings
Cisterns: rain-catching or water-holding basins artificially lined with stone or other hard or impervious material (excluding clay)

column3: Baths of stone, brick, or tile
column4: Baths of stone, brick, or tile
Drains: lined channels, covered or uncovered, or pipes used to carry off rain or bath water
Sewers: lined and covered channels or pipes, primarily for carrying away human waste
Apartment houses: multi-storied dwellings in which rooms are customarily rented to tenants

Permanent fortifications (including palisades around settlements, blockhouses, citadels, and fortified boundaries, but excluding structures whose primary purpose is not defensive, e.g., compounds, fortifications around dwellings which are normally occupied by only one or a few families)
Walls of stone, brick, adobe, or beaten earth (including earthworks) used in fortification
Frontiers fortified with stone walls
Moats (excluding dry ditches but including diverted rivers) used to protect settlements or fortifications
Taverns, inns, or eating houses providing food, drink, and/or lodging
Brothels
Fire brigade
Broad and well-maintained roads connecting settlements

column3: Network of paved roads connecting settlements
column4: Network of paved roads connecting settlements
Bridges or causeways (excluding log spans, vine ropes, and simple pole frameworks)
Way stations or resthouses, not necessarily staffed, which provide lodging for travelers
Rectangular ground plan for dwellings

column3: Houses occupied for at least 10 years
column4: Substantial houses which are lived in for at least 10 years without being permanently abandoned, dismantled, or rebuilt

column3: House interior divided by walls or partitions
column4: Interior space of houses permanently divided by means of walls or partitions (include lofts)
Dwellings divided into three or more walled-off and separate rooms, with some degree of functional differentiation between them
Dwellings which customarily house four or more family units
Multi-storied structures (not meant to include high storage platforms or lofts which do not form a complete story)

column3: Parts of dwellings extensively painted or carved
column4: Walls, ceiling, roof, or other part of dwellings or other structures extensively painted or carved
Cut stone masonry

column3: Stone or brick bases for civic or ceremonial structures
column4: Cut stone or brick substructures (e. g., platforms, truncated pyramids) used as bases for civic or ceremonial structures
Dwellings (including walls) constructed of cut stone or fired brick

column3: Civic or ceremonial buildings of stone or brick
column4: Civic or ceremonial buildings constructed of cut stone or fired brick

column3: Monumental architecture of stone or brick
column4: Monumental architecture of stone or brick (e.g., pyramids, palaces, temples, fortresses, amphitheaters, but excluding solid platforms)
Quarrying of stone for construction (rather than merely dressing loose stones)
Megalithic construction using blocks of stone too heavy to be moved without mechanical devices such as rollers, sledges, ramps, or pulleys
Stone coursing (blocks of cut stone laid in successive horizontal layers)

column3: Rubble used between walls in stone or brick construction
column4: Rubble or some other fill used between walls in stone or brick construction
Fired brick used in construction

column3: Walls of beaten earth or adobe
column4: Walls of beaten earth or adobe
True mortar (i.e., a plastic substance with a chemical bonding action) used in construction

column3: Facing of stone or brick walls or columns
column4: Facing of stone or brick walls or columns with plaster, alabaster, tile, etc.

column3: Roof of tile, brick, dressed stone, planks, etc.
column4: Roof of tile, brick, dressed stone, planks, etc. (i.e., not bark, mud, thatching, or similar material)

column3: House floors made of stone, brick, tile, wood etc.
column4: House floors made of stone, brick, tile, flagstone, or wood (including palm and bamboo)
Stone lintels
Arches of stone or brick (corbeled or keystone)
True (keystone) arch

column3: Stone or brick pillars or columns used structurally
column4: Stone or brick pillars or columns used structurally
Stone or brick stairways (of cut blocks, or carved into living rock)

column3: Buttresses used to strengthen stone or brick walls
column4: Buttresses used to strengthen stone or brick walls

column3: Ornamental carving of stone architectural features
column4: Ornamental carving of stone columns, walls, lintels, or other architectural features of stone

column3: Architectural features cut into living rock
column4: Architectural features (e.g., tombs, stairways) cut into living rock

column3: Fortresses built of stone or brick
column4: Fortresses built of stone or brick (including walled cities and citadels, where people take refuge in time of war)
Elaborations in fortified walls (including, e.g., towers, salients, merlons, but excluding loopholes)
Professional (full-time) carpenters or woodworkers (excluding canoemakers and thatchers)
Professional (full-time) stone masons or bricklayers
Professional (full-time) architects or engineers
Landed property: individual or familial ownership rights over improved land (e.g., cultivated plots, house sites) continue to be exercised, even if land ceases to be occupied or worked

column3: Boundary markers to indicate private property limits
column4: Boundary markers (excluding growing crop plants but including hedges) set up in order to indicate the limits of a piece of private property

column3: Agricultural land commonly bought and sold
column4: Agricultural land commonly bought and sold
Economic speculation in land, foodstuffs, or other commodities a common practice

column3: Inscription of land or other forms of property
column4: Inscription of land or other forms of property (registry of deeds)
Rental of land or dwellings by landlords to tenants as a system of tenure
Share-cropping: a system of land tenure in which the tenant (who is not a serf) pays the landlord a specific proportion or amount of the crop as rent
Leasing of land or dwellings: a formal agreement (not merely observance of custom) in which a tenant’s right of occupancy is guaranteed for a specified period
Serfs: tenants and their descendants legally bound to land which they farm for the benefit of private persons or corporate groups (e.g., feudal lords, temples, monasteries)

column3: Private or government control over natural resources
column4: Private ownership (not ownership by a sib or a local group) or government control exercised over scarce or limited natural resources (e.g., clay pits, clam beds, salt, water holes, mineral deposits, grove of wild fruit trees) rather than free access to them

column3: Distinctive marks used to indicate property ownership
column4: Seals, brands, or other distinctive marks used to indicate ownership of manufactured property

Marked differences in wealth (e.g., real property, livestock, precious metals, slaves; but excluding wives, ceremonial bundles) among members of the society (other than the difference between the principal political leader or religious specialist and everyone else)

column3: Feasts or gift-giving ceremonies showcasing wealth
column4: Feasts or gift-giving ceremonies in which much wealth is displayed or consumed, including those for state purposes
Recorded inventories of property owned (e.g., with pebbles, knotted cords, notched sticks, clay tablets, ledgers)

Most individual (not family) property owned and in the possession of a person at the time of his death (exclude property lent out and still outstanding) transmitted by inheritance rather than being buried, destroyed, or otherwise disposed of at the death of the owner
Testamentary disposition of property, by a written will, through a formal executor, or orally in the presence of a witness (excluding incorporeal property)
Craft specialization: some craft(s) which only a limited number of persons in the society practice (excluding the making of religious or ceremonial objects by shamans or priests, or chiefs)
A significant amount of craft production primarily for economic exchange rather than for personal consumption
Full-time craft specialists (e.g., brewer, lapidary, tailor, baker, tanner)

Service specialization: some services which only a limited number of persons in the society provide (excluding religious specialists and curers, but including clans and other groups that perform specialized services)
Full-time service specialists other than religious practitioners (e.g., tattooer, barber, accountant, lawyer, physician)
Professional barbers or hairdressers
Professional porters or bearers
Processing or preparation of food by full-time specialists (e.g., millers, butchers, cooks, bakers) other than household servants or slaves
Professional brewers or wine makers
Clothing or shoes manufactured by full-time specialists

column3: Medium of exchange used in trade
column4: Medium of exchange, which is frequently used in trade for a variety of commodities
Currency: a medium valued primarily for its use in economic exchanges rather than as an ornamental or consumable good, and which may be exchanged freely for any goods or commodities which are traded

column3: Economic exchange in currency or money
column4: A significant amount of economic exchange carried out by means of currency or money

column3: Metallic currency valued according to weight
column4: Metallic currency valued according to weight (including coins)

column3: Two or more metals used as currency
column4: Two or more metals of different monetary value used as currency
Coined money
Coins of different denominations

column3: Animals or foodstuffs lent out at interest
column4: Animals, seed crops, or foodstuffs lent out at interest

column3: Money or goods lent out at interest
column4: Money or goods (not including animals or foodstuffs) lent out at interest
Professional moneylenders
Banks, which pay interest on deposits and make loans

column3: Pledging of movable property as debt security
column4: Pledging of items of movable property as security on a debt

column3: Pledging of oneself or family member as debt security
column4: Pledging of oneself or members of one’s family as security on a debt
Mortgage: a legal instrument offering land or houses as security to guarantee the repayment of a loan
Insurance: protection against calamities (e.g., fire, theft, loss of merchandise at sea) offered by an underwriter for a premium
Trade between communities

column3: Economically important trade between communities or regions
column4: Economically important trade carried out between communities or regions (including that conducted through itinerant merchants)

column3: Economically important trade in finished goods between communities
column4: Economically important trade in which finished goods (excluding food) are traded to other communities or societies (including exchanges conducted through itinerant merchants)
Full-time specialist(s) in trade
Trading outposts maintained outside the territory of the society
Markets, in which a variety of goods are traded
Daily and permanent markets
Specialized market(s) within a town or city (e.g., fish market, cattle market, textile market, flower market)
Itinerant merchants or specialized traders who are members of the society itself (rather than foreigners), and who remain such even if they trade outside the society
Sedentary merchants who operate fixed commercial establishments outside the market area
Wholesale merchants

column3: Professional merchants undertake large-scale trading expeditions
column4: Professional merchants undertake large-scale trading expeditions

column3: Merchants form a significant segment of the society
column4: Merchants form a significant segment of the society

column3: Merchant class with particular rights or restrictions
column4: Merchants constitute a class, with prescribed advantages (e.g., exemption from military service or corvée labor) and/or disabilities (e.g., exclusion from holding office, subjection to discriminatory taxation)
Contracts: economic agreements legally enforceable by a higher authority

column3: Economic transactions formally witnessed or notarized
column4: Economic transactions formally witnessed or notarized
Commercial agreements negotiated between states

column3: Commerical transactions authenticated with seals, signatures, or marks
column4: Seals, signatures, or individual marks used to authenticate commercial transactions
Commercial warehouses used to store privately-owned merchandise

column3: Written documents used for large-scale goods shipments
column4: Bills of lading or other written documents used in large-scale shipments of goods
Long-term commercial records kept
Companies: business enterprises including two or more persons who are organized to carry out commercial or industrial operations
Corporations: companies, chartered by the state, the members of which have limited liability
Labor mobilized by the offer of compensation (rather than by a kinship obligation), e.g., food and drink, payment in kind or money, salary

column3: Hire of individuals for unskilled manual labor
column4: Individuals commonly hired to perform unskilled manual labor
Wage labor, for which payment is made at definite rates and intervals

column3: Enforced mobilization of labor for public projects
column4: Enforced mobilization of labor for community, tribal, or state projects (excluding military conscription)
Corvée (draft labor exacted by a supra-community authority or agency)

column3: Institutional employment of artisans and laborers
column4: Artisans and laborers attached to or employed on a regular basis (rather than under the corvée) by political or religious institutions (tribe or state, temple or church)
Overseers, who superintend the labor of slaves or other workers (other than majordomos on private estates)
Factories: enterprises in which workers, under unified supervision, produce goods by performing differentiated tasks (including temple workshops)
Trademarks placed on articles to identify the maker or manufacturer (e.g., potter’s mark, swordsmith’s signature, mint marks)

column3: Class of freemen artisans selling their products or services
column4: Class of artisans who are freemen and who sell their products or services

column3: Neighborhoods of specialized artisans within towns or cities
column4: Neighborhoods of specialized artisans within towns or cities

column3: Certain industries concentrated in particular villages, towns, or cities
column4: Certain industries concentrated in particular villages, towns, or cities

column3: Guilds of craft or service specialists
column4: Guilds (i.e., cooperative associations) of craft or service specialists, including labor unions
Guilds of merchants or bankers
Taxation in kind (including produce from land farmed for the state, but excluding required contributions to community projects or ceremonies)
Taxation in currency

column3: Official tax, tribute, or customs collectors
column4: Official tax, tribute, or customs collectors (excluding local chiefs)
Collection of taxes in kind or currency on a regular schedule and at fixed rates
Special taxes, in addition to regular taxes, levied for special needs (e.g., war expenses, public works, royal marriages; but excluding primarily religious taxes)

column3: Tax obligations commutable into state service
column4: Tax obligations commutable into service to the state or its representative

column3: Assessors appraising property for tax calculation
column4: Assessors (as distinct from tax collectors) who appraise land or other property, and determine the amount of taxes to be paid
Taxes assessed on land
Taxes assessed on movable property (including crops and livestock)
Taxes on commerce (e.g., sales taxes, taxes on goods brought to market, ground rents on places in market)
Taxes on the manufacture, sale, or consumption of luxury goods
Inheritance taxes
Duties on goods imported, or transported across internal boundaries
Tolls collected for the use of roads, bridges, or ferries

column3: Produce from private lands for the ruler or state
column4: Produce of certain privately-worked lands set aside for the chief, king, tribe, or state (exclufing chief's land worked by the people at large for his support)

column3: Superintendent of royal or state herds, lands, or forests
column4: Superintendent who supervises the maintenance of royal or state herds, lands, or forests

column3: The extent of landholdings limited by law or decree
column4: The extent of landholdings limited by law or decree
State fixes rent or rent ceilings on privately owned lands or dwellings

column3: Government operates industries or exploits resources directly
column4: Government operates industries or exploits resources directly (e.g., weaving, armoring, goldsmithing; mines, salt deposits)

column3: Government derives revenue from industries and resources indirectly
column4: Government derives revenue from industries and resources indirectly (e.g., licenses salt production, wine making, ironworking, mining)

column3: Government registration or licensing of specialists or merchants
column4: Government registration or licensing of craft specialists, service specialists, or merchants for purposes of taxation or control

column3: State contracts private enterprises for certain functions or goods
column4: State lets out contracts to private enterprises for the performance of certain functions (e.g., public works, tax collection) or the supply of certain goods

column3: State sells or auctions public property
column4: State sells or auctions public property (e.g., public lands, confiscated property, captured war booty) to raise revenue

column3: Government trades commodities on the open market
column4: Government buys or sells commodities on the open market

column3: State obtains loans from private or foreign sources
column4: State obtains loans from private sources or from other states

column3: Governmental supervision or regulation of commerce
column4: Governmental supervision or regulation of commerce (e.g., inspecting weights and measures, maintaining order in markets, settling commercial disputes, enforcing payment of debts, fixing price levels)

column3: Government inspection or regulation of places of entertainment
column4: Government inspection, licensing, or regulation of places of entertainment (e.g., taverns, gambling houses, brothels)
State-directed trade (i.e., trade carried on by agents of the state with other societies)

column3: Wage levels of certain occupations fixed by law
column4: Wage levels of certain occupations fixed by law

column3: Interest rates fixed by law and usury punishable
column4: Interest rates fixed by law and usury punishable

column3: Distraint of property for debt default or tax nonpayment
column4: Distraint of property (by government officials, not private seizure) for default of debts or nonpayment of taxes

column3: Government distributes food in times of shortage or famine
column4: Government relieves conditions of food shortage or famine by distributing or selling foodstuffs

column3: Public or church support of the destitute
column4: Public, government, or church support (as against support by kinsmen or tribesmen only) of the destitute (e.g., widows, orphans, aged, or infirm), excluding becoming wards or servants of the chief or king by indigent person

Social (rather than territorial) segments above the level of the extended family or household (e.g., lineages, sibs, moieties, marriage classes, social classes, castes, age grades, men’s clubs, secret societies, warrior societies, ceremonial teams, craft guilds)
Two or more different types of social segments
Unilineal kin groups (segments) beyond extended families (including royal or chiefly lineages)

column3: Genealogies for at least five generations
column4: Genealogies traced back reliably for at least five generations
Voluntary associations, permanent and corporate, based on principles other than kinship or age
Blood brotherhood or other special friendships solemnized by ceremonies

column3: Occupational classes, castes, or descent groups
column4: Occupational classes, castes, or descent groups (excluding slaves, but including clans with specific duties)

column3: Bride price, bride service, or gift exchange
column4: Marriage formalized by bride price, bride service, or gift exchange between the bride and groom or their families
Dowry (as distinguished from the contribution of the bride or her family in gift exchange)
Marriage celebrated with a feast

column3: Marriages performed by priests or state officials
column4: Marriages performed or registered by priests or officials of the state (not including the mere blessing of the couple by a priest)
Well-defined and significant differences in social status (other than the difference between the principal political leader or shaman and everyone else, or differences based on age or sex)

column3: Wealth accumulation brings prestige or influence
column4: The accumulation of wealth in movable property or land, even without its redistribution, brings considerable prestige or influence
Stratification of the society into distinct social classes (excluding status distinctions based only on age or sex, and the ranking of clans or subclans)

column3: Social stratification into at least three classes
column4: Stratification of the society into at least three distinct social classes

column3: Differences of rank within the upper classes
column4: Differences of rank within the upper class(es) other than that based on political or religious office or sex

column3: Class distinctions in legal liability for offenses
column4: Class distinctions in legal liability for offenses (i.e., members of the various social classes have different rights under the law)

column3: Ornaments, clothing or other marks distinguishing social classes
column4: Special ornaments, differences in clothing, or other marks, which distinguish members of one class from the rest of the society

column3: Insignia of noble or high rank
column4: Insignia of noble or high rank (e.g, ear plugs, special hairdos, coats of arms) meant primarily to indicate status rather than being largely ornamental
Sumptuary laws concerning dress, adornment, or other manifestations of wealth and serving to maintain class distinctions

column3: Some society members have superior residences
column4: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) have categorically superior residences

column3: Some society members own more land
column4: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) own significantly more land than others
Majordomos supervise staffs of private households or estates (other than that of the political leader)

column3: Some society members have numerous wives or concubines
column4: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) have numerous wives or concubines (at least 8 or 10)

column3: Some society members have servants or retainers
column4: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) have permanent servants or retainers (other than slaves)

column3: Persons of high rank have special privileges
column4: Persons of high rank (other than the political leader) have special privileges (e.g., exemption from taxation or corvée, right to hold political office, right to remain seated in the king’s presence) excluding privileges relating to dress and ornament

column3: Competitive sports or spectacles staged by the upper classes
column4: Competitive sports or spectacles staged by the political leader or members of the upper classes

column3: Hunting primarily an upper class pastime
column4: Hunting primarily a pastime of the chief, king, or upper classes

column3: Codes of social conduct distinguishing class or status
column4: Elaborate code of social conduct serves to distinguish between social classes or individuals of different social positions

column3: Class differences in disposal of the dead
column4: Status (excluding age and sex) class, or caste differences in disposal of the dead (based on social rather than religious status; exclude shamans and priests)

column3: Some society members buried with wealth or animal sacrifices
column4: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) buried with large amounts of wealth, or have a considerable number of animals sacrificed at their death

column3: Some society members buried with wives, retainers or slaves
column4: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) buried with or accompanied in death by wives, concubines, retainers, or slaves
Some members of the society (other than the political leader) buried in elaborate tombs or graves (e.g., burial mounds, cist graves, thatched buildings)
War captives or persons bought outside the society kept as slaves without subsequently being liberated, killed, or granted equal status with native-born members of the society
Debtors or criminals made slaves, or other freeborn members of the society (including wives and children) sold into slavery

column3: Slaves branded, tonsured, or otherwise identified
column4: Slaves branded, tonsured, or otherwise identified
Some slaves kept as personal servants and not used in economically productive activities (including cooking)

Slaves as a class economically significant, i.e., they add to the economy more than they consume (produce food, make goods, or yield a product in significant amounts, rather than merely doing odd work)

column3: Slaves bought and sold within the society
column4: Slaves bought and sold within the society (excluding the selling into slavery of freeborn members of the society)
Slave markets
Hereditary slavery
Manumission of slaves common
Communities (or camps) continuously grouped (year-round) into larger political units which recognize some central authority
Districts or provinces, each comprising several villages or communities, are permanently grouped into a larger political unit

column3: Three or more levels of territorial administration
column4: Three or more levels of territorial administration above the community (e.g., 1. district, 2. province, 3. quarter, 4. kingdom)

State: permanent organization of a number of supra-community units (districts, tribes, or provinces) into a single political unit under centralized control, involving at least (a) some power to collect revenue, (b) the power to conscript men for work or war, (c) some centralized judicial authority, and (d) the power to formulate and execute policy
Population of the state 100,000 or above
Population of the state 1,000,000 or above
Citizenship: citizens have certain rights under the law which non-citizens do not have
State or tribe has capital city, town, or village
Towns or cities divided into quarters or wards for civil or judicial purposes
State endeavors to maintain administrative units of approximately equal size at each of several levels by redistricting or by the movement of populations

column3: Permission to move between administrative units
column4: Government permission required to move from one administrative unit to another
Colonists sent to settle in conquered or newly-opened territory

column3: Young persons sent to capital for training, service or as hostages
column4: Young persons sent to capital for training or royal service or as hostages

column3: Headman, chief, king, or council of elders
column4: A generally recognized agent or agency of the society (e.g., headman, chief, king, council of elders) makes decisions or policy affecting the society as a whole

Political leader(s) has the power, by threat or exercise of active sanctions, to make individuals comply with his decisions (e.g., can assign tasks, draft labor, impose taxes, command military service)
Political leader(s) exercises judicial power (decides guilt and decrees punishment, or settles cases appealed to him; does not merely mediate)

column3: Political leader exercises supreme judicial authority
column4: Political leader(s) exercises supreme judicial authority, e.g., has the power to reverse decisions of inferior judges or courts in civil or criminal cases
Chiefly or kingly line through which political leadership is customarily transmitted

column3: Heir apparent undergoes training for future office
column4: Heir apparent undergoes rigorous or intensive training or education as preparation for his future office, including, e.g. serving as governor of a province

column3: Property qualifications required for public office
column4: Property qualifications required for appointment or formal election to public office
Secondary political leader(s) who have authority over segments of the society (e.g., sub-chiefs, house chiefs, clan chiefs, governors)
Formally constituted council (permanent or ad hoc) or official who advises, deliberates with, or controls the political leader

column3: Non-territorial advisors or administrative civil officials
column4: Non-territorial advisors or administrative civil officials: functionaries who advise or act at the direction of the political leader, but who are not personal servants or retainers (e.g., talking chiefs)
Specialized officials in charge of one or more activities or enterprises controlled or supervised by the government
Hierarchy of non-territorial administrative officials (excluding palace hierarchy)

column3: Secondary political officials may appoint their subordinates
column4: Secondary political officials may appoint their subordinates
Provincial or district administrative centers where officials appointed by the state (other than local chiefs) collect taxes or maintain order
Towns or cities within a larger political unit have municipal governments
Secretariat, in charge of drafting, promulgating, and circulating laws or royal decrees
Accountant or treasurer who keeps track of the wealth accumulated by the chief, king, or state
Inspectors, censors, or secret agents who examine records or investigate the functioning of officials, popular discontent, etc.
Census taken (including simple enumerations or head counts)
Organized messenger or courier system which links together most of the society’s territory
Ministries: government departments headed by ministers and having full-time staffs of officials and clerks
Ministry of revenue or finance
Ministry of public works
Ministry of justice

column3: Ministry of religious affairs, rites, or ceremonials
column4: Ministry of religious affairs, rites, or ceremonials
Ministry of foreign affairs
Ministry of war
Prime minister: principal administrative official below the ruler who initiates or executes policy

column3: Council of ministers advising the ruler
column4: Council of ministers forming a regular advisory body to the ruler
Devices used to confirm or authenticate official orders, decrees, actions, and transactions (e.g., seals, signatures, rings, or other symbols)
Auditing procedures to check for errors or embezzlement in government financial accounts
Budget: a comprehensive and itemized estimate of anticipated revenues and expenditures, periodically prepared by government officials
Annals of state affairs regularly kept by official historian(s)
Archives in which official records and state papers are kept

column3: State officials paid a fixed salary
column4: State officials paid a fixed salary
Officials' salaries paid, at least in part, in currency rather than in kind
Codified regulations minutely govern the constitution and operation of the administrative structure

column3: Political leader is a full-time specialist
column4: Political leader does not ordinarily engage in subsistence

column3: Political leader abstains from low-status activities
column4: Political leader may not engage in certain common economic activities, which are considered to be beneath his status

column3: Political leader entertains on a lavish scale
column4: Political leader entertains on a lavish scale

column3: Political leader bestows land, slaves, rank
column4: Political leader bestows land, slaves, wealth, women, or noble rank for services rendered
Political leader appoints and deposes subordinate political officials
Political leader promulgates laws, issues decrees, or makes proclamations to the populace (not just orders that are obeyed)
Political leader grants formal audiences to hear grievances or petitions (exclude appeal in legal cases)

column3: Political leader travels around the kingdom
column4: Political leader makes regular visits to various parts of the kingdom to examine conditions, hear cases, collect taxes, awe his subjects, etc.

column3: Political leader travels with a retinue
column4: Political leader travels with a retinue
Political leader exercises considerable control over the activities of temples or the church (e.g., performs investiture of priests, endows temples)

column3: Political leader performs essential societal rituals
column4: Political leader performs rituals considered essential for the welfare of the society, and which only he can perform
Special ceremony for installation or investiture of new political leader (e.g., oath of office, coronation)

column3: Political leader has special symbols of office
column4: Political leader has special symbols of office or authority (e.g., throne, crown, scepter, seal, robes)
Displays of special deference to political leader (e.g., carrying in a litter, averting the eyes, bowing)

column3: Officials or sub-chiefs swear allegiance to the leader
column4: Officials, vassals, sub-chiefs, or courtiers swear allegiance to the chief, king, or state

column3: Political leader addressed by honorific titles
column4: Political leader addressed or referred to by various honorific titles
Lese majesty — an offense against the dignity, person, or property of the ruler — severely punished
Ruler is considered divine, semi-divine, or sacred, or traces his descent from a god
Political leader buried with large amounts of wealth

column3: Political leader buried with wives or slaves
column4: Wives, concubines, retainers, or slaves of political leader buried with him or otherwise killed at the time of his death
Political leader buried in an elaborate tomb or grave (e.g., burial mound, cist grave, thatched building, pyramid)

column3: Special treatment to preserve leader’s corpse
column4: Special treatment (e.g., desiccation, embalming) to preserve the political leader’s corpse or part thereof (not just the bones)
Deceased former political leader especially reverenced (e.g., his spirit invoked or propitiated, monuments erected to his memory)

column3: Ruler receives food and goods as gifts, tribute or taxes
column4: Chief or king receives large amounts of food and/or other goods as gifts, tribute, taxes, or fines
Political leader lives in a special residence or compound categorically superior to any other residence
Royal estates, residences, or preserves outside the capital which are the property of the ruler
Political leader has full-time personal attendants or retainers

column3: Royal household maintained by a steward and staff
column4: Royal or chiefly household maintained by a steward and staff
Court, a body of officials, members of the upper classes, retainers, entertainers, etc., surrounding the chief or king

column3: Ruler has significantly more wives or concubines
column4: Chief or king has significantly more wives or concubines than anyone else
Chief or king has a harem (a special residence(s) supervised by a responsible official(s), e.g., a eunuch)
Bodyguard to protect the ruler’s person

column3: Private tutors for children of nobles
column4: Private tutors retained at court to instruct prince(s) and/or children of nobles

column3: Political leader has storehouse or treasury
column4: Political leader has storehouse or treasury (for hard goods or valuables, rather than for food)
Formal treaties (recorded or witnessed and sworn) concluded between societies to establish alliances, to settle disputes, or to end wars
Ambassador(s): diplomatic representative acting in regular relations with a foreign government
Diplomatic missions by government officials carried out for specific purposes
Passports, visas, or tallies to control the entry or exit of persons, native or foreign
Superordinate tribe or state which receives tribute, labor, soldiers, or other recognition of obligation from subordinate or vassal tribe(s) or state(s)

column3: Resident officials overseeing native rulers of subordinate states
column4: Resident political officials who oversee native rulers of feudatory or tributary states
Composition: redress of death or bodily injury by payment of an indemnity to the victim or his relatives (with or without a formal judicial proceeding)

column3: Ordeals or oaths to establish guilt or settle disputes
column4: Ordeals or oaths to establish guilt or innocence or to settle disputes prescribed or enforced (exclude torture applied to extract a confession)

column3: Mediation used to settle inter-community disputes
column4: Mediation or formal legal procedure customarily used to settle at least one type of dispute within the political unit

column3: Land disputes settled by political or judicial authority
column4: Disputes over land settled by political or judicial authority, rather than only by mediation or fighting

Judicial process, in which an individual or limited group (e.g., council of elders, tribal chief, court of law) considers evidence and renders judgment in a dispute, or of an accused person, on behalf of the society
Court trials, held under specialized judges or magistrates who hear testimony and weigh evidence, interpret the law or customary law, and render a decision in civil or criminal cases

column3: Judicial system of higher and lower courts
column4: Judicial system of higher and lower courts, cases being referred to one or the other according to their nature, with decisions of lower courts perhaps appealable to higher courts
Specialized courts (e.g., commercial courts, military courts, ecclesiastical courts, divorce courts)
Legal counsel: specialized advocates or lawyers who interpret the law or act for clients in legal cases

column3: Oaths or affirmations of truthful testimony
column4: Oaths or affirmations of truthful testimony required of witnesses in legal trials

column3: Oaths of compurgation accepted as evidence of innocence
column4: Oaths of compurgation accepted as evidence of innocence at legal trials

column3: Perjury or false testimony punishable by law
column4: Perjury or false testimony in court legal cases punishable by law
Judges: officials whose sole function it is to apply the law and render decisions in civil or criminal cases
Police: specialized individual or force charged with keeping the peace, enforcement of norms, or the apprehension and detention of offenders
Specialized public executioner
Law: a body of explicitly formulated secular norms, interpreted, applied, and enforced by a constituted authority
Laws recurrently decreed by a ruler or enacted by a legislative body
Code of laws (explicit and recorded) which covers social, political, and/or economic relations

column3: Offenses against persons punishable by law
column4: Offenses against persons (e.g., sorcery — if actually practiced, assault, maiming, rape, murder) punishable under law or custom by formal means

column3: Offenses against property punishable by law
column4: Offenses against property (e.g., theft, arson, willful or inadvertent destruction) subject to indemnification or punishment under law or custom by formal means

column3: Obstruction of justice punishable under law
column4: Obstruction of justice (e.g., harboring of criminals, refusing to give evidence) punishable under law

column3: Laws governing marriage, abortion, or adoption
column4: Laws governing marriage, divorce, abortion, infanticide, or adoption
Laws governing inheritance

column3: Laziness, malingering, or vagrancy punishable by law
column4: Laziness, malingering, or vagrancy punishable by law

column3: Libel, slander, or malicious lying punishable by law
column4: Libel, slander, or malicious lying punishable by law
Laws regulating borrowing and lending
Building codes: laws regulating house construction (e.g., prescribing building materials, limiting number of stories)
Sacrilege — irreverence or disrespect toward a sacred person, place, custom, or object — severely punished

column3: Religious law enforced by political officials
column4: Religious law enforced by political officials
Statute of limitations specifying the time within which offenders must be brought to trial to be punishable

column3: Offenses punished by a designated agent rather than by the offended party
column4: Most offenses regularly punished by a designated or permanent agent of the society rather than by the offended parties themselves

column3: Crimes punishable by public authorities only
column4: Crimes legally punishable by public authorities only; private action illegal
Certain offenses punished by fines (in currency or in kind) paid to the lineage, sib or village, tribe or state, of which part may go to the offended party (including penalty feasts)

column3: Offenses punished by confiscation of property
column4: Certain offenses punished by confiscation of property, of which part may go to the offended party

column3: Political authority retains fines or confiscated property
column4: Fines collected or property confiscated by political authority and not shared with the offended party (unless he is the political leader)

Corporal punishment (including mutilation, shaving off hair) meted out for certain offenses by an authorized agent of the society (other than the offended party or his kin unless he is the political leader)
Incarceration of convicted offenders (in shackles, stocks, pens, cages, or prisons)

column3: Offenses punished by slavery or hard labor
column4: Certain offenses punished by slavery or by terms at hard labor
Death penalty decreed by custom or after judicial procedure for certain crimes, and exacted openly by someone acting with the explicit approval of the society

column3: Commutation of certain sentences upon payment
column4: Commutation of sentences for certain crimes may be granted upon payment of a fixed amount

column3: Political leader sometimes pardons convicted offenders
column4: Political leader sometimes pardons convicted offenders

column3: General amnesties granted on special occasions
column4: General amnesties granted on special occasions

column3: Violation of secular law incurs punishment by gods and secular punishment
column4: Violation of secular legal norms automatically incurs punishment by gods during the individual’s lifetime, as well as secular punishment by a formally designated agent of the society

column3: Warfare for reasons beyond personal conflicts or preemptive defense
column4: Warfare initiated for considerations other than (or in addition to) the avenging of insults, personal injury, murder, witchcraft, the stealing of women, trespass, or forestalling an enemy attack
Economic considerations (e.g., territorial acquisition, the capture of booty, the taking of slaves) important in the initiation of warfare
Warfare initiated in order to impose religious dogma or to make religious observances (e.g., human sacrifice)

column3: Formal warning or declaration of war
column4: Formal warning, challenges, or declaration of war, including the displaying of symbols, customarily given
Recognized war leader(s) (other than a political leader) who regularly leads the men of the society against the enemy (e.g., war chief, general)
Professional military commanders (e.g., generals) who regularly lead the army in time of war
Professional middle-level military officials (e.g., centurions, lieutenants, captains)
Body of specially trained or highly skilled warriors (as distinct from the rest of the fighting men)
Standing army, organized around a core of professional soldiers, and continuously maintained
Militia: a semimilitary organization with officers who keep its units in readiness to quell uprisings or repel invasions
Military conscription (those disinclined to fight either coerced into doing so, allowed to commute, or else subject to punishment)

column3: Military or corvée obligations fulfilled through substitutes or payments
column4: Substitutes may be hired or commutation paid to fulfill military or corvée obligations
Troops receive fixed pay (over and above, or instead of, a share of the booty)
Mercenaries (i.e., paid foreign troops) used in warfare
Soldiers or officers take oath of allegiance
Fighting force customarily divided into subunits
Army organized into groups of units which are successively more inclusive (e.g., platoons, companies, regiments, divisions)

column3: Organized war preparation drills and exercises
column4: Organized drills or exercises carried out to prepare for war
Differentiated military units (e.g., spearmen, bowmen, slingers, cavalry)
Cavalry
Military engineers

column3: Baggage trains used to transport the army’s supplies
column4: Baggage trains used to transport the army’s supplies

Pitched battles, involving considerable hand-to-hand fighting, initiated, in which the objective is to destroy or drive off the enemy fighting force, or capture (rather than merely raid) enemy settlements
Fighters begin battle in formation (including arrangement in a straight line)
Soldiers fight closely aligned or as compact units, rather than as separate individuals
Formal rules governing conduct of soldiers and officers in war
Arsenals or armories where government stockpiles of weapons are maintained

column3: Cutting or thrusting weapons used in warfare
column4: Cutting or thrusting weapons used in warfare
Defensive body armor (exclude shields and helmets)
Metal armor used in warfare
Chariots used in warfare
Emblems, banners, or special objects which serve to identify military units, or act as rallying points, are carried into battle

column3: Musical instruments used for battle signals
column4: Drums, horns, trumpets, etc., used to signal commands in battle or to encourage troops (excluding the use of these instruments merely to frighten the enemy)
Espionage, by special agents who gather strategic information in foreign territory by hiding their purpose and/or identity but not their persons
Sieges laid to enemy fortifications strong enough to resist immediate assault
Permanently garrisoned forts (excluding observation posts, walled towns and cities)
Battering rams

column3: Assault ladders or towers used in sieges
column4: Assault ladders or towers used in sieges
Siege ramps

column3: Catapult-type devices used as siege engines
column4: Catapult-type devices used as siege engines
Body trophies (e.g., heads, scalps, hands) taken in war or from sacrificed prisoners
Considerable booty taken during successful military campaigns
Adult males frequently taken captive in warfare
Cannibalism of war captives

column3: War captives regularly sacrificed to gods
column4: War captives regularly sacrificed to god(s)

column3: War captives kept for ransom or held as hostages
column4: War captives kept for ransom or held as hostages

column3: Special ornaments for brave or wounded warriors
column4: Special ornaments, insignia, or appellations awarded for prowess or wounds received in battle
Outstanding warriors rewarded with gifts of property, women, or slaves, or appointment to official positions
Nobility or distinctly high social status attainable through war exploits

column3: Penalty for cowardice, desertion, or insurrection
column4: Death, confiscation of property, or other severe punishment may be penalty for cowardice in battle, desertion, or insurrection

column3: Formal ceremonies to conclude inter-societal hostilities
column4: Formal ceremonies (including the making of treaties) to conclude hostilities with other societies

column3: Military prowess exhibited in parades or reviews
column4: Military parades or reviews in which military skill and prowess are exhibited (excluding celebrations held for returning warriors)
Territory of vanquished enemy annexed
Peoples of vanquished enemy subjugated and held under effective control

column3: Defeated political leaders pledge allegiance to conquerors
column4: Defeated political leader(s) or his relative(s) retained in authority over his territory on pledge of allegiance to conquerors
Indemnities or reparations (as distinct from tribute) exacted from defeated enemies

column3: Permanent settlements built in conquered territory
column4: Permanent settlements built in conquered territory
Supernatural being(s) who currently intervenes for the benefit of suppliants
Ancestral spirits propitiated and invoked

God(s): specifically personified supernatural being(s) (not impersonal force) who is not particular to locations or to kinship segments (exclude, e.g., ancestral, guardian, and other personal spirits), to whom prayers are directed and who intervenes for the benefit of the society or its members
Sun god worshipped (i.e., propitiated and invoked)
God of war (not necessarily connected exclusively with war) worshipped
Lawgiver god, who on more than one occasion has enunciated extensive rules for governing human conduct, worshipped

Patron gods or saints (not including guardian spirits), who afford protection to groups of individuals engaged in particular occupations or activities (e.g., god of merchants, god of hunters, god of travelers, god of blacksmiths, god of war)

Pantheon of gods worshipped (propitiated and invoked); (applies only to differentiated gods who actively control spheres of life or nature, e.g., rain god, war god, fire god, fertility goddess, love goddess)
One god in the pantheon of differentiated gods worshipped as paramount

column3: Life and death affects the afterlife
column4: Manner of living or dying affects the status or condition of the soul after death
Offerings (including libations and sacrifices)

Animal sacrifices directed to supernatural beings to placate them or gain their favor
Human sacrifice directed to supernatural beings to placate them or gain their favor
Private worship of supernatural beings through personally owned (rather than societally maintained) idols, altars, or shrines

column3: Priests perform private ceremonies for payment
column4: Private ceremonies or sacrifices performed by priests (not shamans or medicine men) on behalf of individuals for payment

column3: Priests conduct sacrifices on behalf of the society
column4: Priests conduct sacrifices on behalf of the society, or a significant segment thereof, to ward off calamities, solicit benefits, or offer thanks

column3: Rites of passage performed by priests
column4: Rites of passage performed by priests
Rites to promote fertility of the soil, to bring rain, or to celebrate the harvest performed seasonally (rather than merely when the crop is in danger)
Thank offerings to supernatural being(s)

column3: Pre-battle rituals performed by religious specialists
column4: Offerings, sacrifices, prayers, or other rituals carried out by religious specialists before battle
Victory offerings made to supernatural being(s) after successful military campaign
Offerings or sacrifices made in connection with housebuilding or the erection of other structures
Religious pilgrimages to distant shrines or sacred places
Votive offerings or ceremonies or votive pilgrimages made
Idols: durable representations made in the likeness of supernatural beings through or in which they are worshipped
Oracles: shrines, places, or objects where, or by means of which, a medium transmits answers to questions posed to a god or spirit (exclude the use of animals for augury)
Shrines, altars, ceremonial platforms, or other sacred places where religious practices (e.g., offerings, rituals, prayers) are regularly or repeatedly carried out

column3: Incense burned for ceremonial or ritual purposes
column4: Incense burned for ceremonial or ritual purposes
Ritual or liturgical (written) texts
Special supernatural practitioners (e.g., shamans, diviners, priests, monks)

column3: Religious specialists supported by individuals or society
column4: Religious specialist(s) supported (fully or almost fully) by individuals, the community, tribe, or state

column3: Divination specialists consulted before important undertakings
column4: Specialists (e.g., astrologers) concerned exclusively with divination and related activities (exclude shamans) are consulted before undertakings important to the society or the political leader

Functionally specialized priests (e.g., interpreters of oracles or dreams, sacrificial priests, funerary priests, war priests)

column3: Priests formally invested in their office
column4: Priests formally invested in their office by chief, king, or higher priest

column3: Head priest has considerable political influence
column4: Head priest (including priest-chief or priest-king) has considerable political influence

column3: Women consecrated to a temple or a god service
column4: Women consecrated to a temple or to the service of a god (e.g., priestesses, virgins, nuns)

column3: Priests distinguished by visible status marks
column4: Priests or monks always distinguished by specific visible marks of their status (e.g., tonsure, special garments)

column3: Priests follow strict rules of discipline

column3: Temples dedicated to specific gods or saints
column4: Differentiated temples dedicated to specific gods or saints

Church: religious institution which encompasses a number of priests and temples (or monks and monasteries) and which is unified by a set of common beliefs and observances
Temple or church receives donations (other than offerings left to supernatural beings)
Temple or church exacts tithes, receives the produce of a fixed portion of cultivated lands, or claims a set part of personal incomes

column3: Church owns large amounts of land
column4: Church owns large amounts of land

Pottery (either made or commonly used)
Painted pottery made
Effigy vessels made

column3: Large ceramic vessels for storing or transporting grain or liquids
column4: Large ceramic vessels made expressly for storing or transporting grain or liquids

Pottery kilns
Professional (full-time) potters
Professional (full-time) painters or sculptors
Terra-cotta (baked clay) figurines or statues as art or ceremonial objects (free-standing, not appliquéd on pots or walls)
Statues or figurines carved in hard wood or ivory
Stone statues (or figurines) as art or ceremonial objects
Heroic or gigantic stone sculpture
Reliefs, intaglios, or friezes carved into dressed stone surfaces
Murals or frescoes painted on faced stone or brick walls
Glass manufactured

column3: Mosaics of stone, brick, tile, or glass
column4: Mosaics of stone, brick, tile, or glass

column3: Ground or polished stone or shell cutting tools
column4: Ground or polished stone or shell cutting tools
Metal axes or adzes made
Metal-pointed plowshares

column3: Animal-, wind-, or water-powered grinding devices
column4: Animal-, wind-, or water-powered devices for grinding grain
Mechanical devices for raising water (e.g., shadoof, water wheel, water screw)
Wheeled vehicles
Scales or balances
Techniques of wood joining beyond lashing and gluing (e.g., use of pegs, nails, dovetailing, sewing)
Furniture: e.g., stools, benches, platform beds, hammocks
Lock and keys
Mirrors
Spindle
Heddle loom
Plant fibers woven into cloth
Animal fibers (e.g., hair, wool, fur, silk) woven into cloth (exclude unraveling and reweaving of woolen cloth obtained by trade)

Dyeing (not painting or smearing) of textiles, yarn, bark cloth, or pandanus leaves

Forging (hammering metal into shape while hot)
Mining of ores (excluding placers)

Casting in molds
Lost-wax casting (cire perdue)

column4: Altering the hardness of metals by annealing (heating and slow cooling) or tempering (heating and rapid cooling by immersion in a liquid)

column4: Soldering, welding, or riveting used to join metals
Decorative metal-working techniques (e.g., gilding, embossing, engraving, inlaying)
Copper weapons, utensils, or instruments in common use
Bronze or brass weapons, utensils, or instruments in common use

column4: Ornaments and jewelry of gold, silver, or other precious metals made or used

column4: Vessel hulls built from several planks (excluding wash strakes)
Vessels propelled by oars (not paddles)

Steering oar or rudder
Devices for stabilizing vessels (e.g., keels, centerboards, outriggers)
Cabins on board vessels
Decked vessels, with cabin or storage space below decks
Merchant vessels, operated by professional merchants and specially designed to transport cargo

Professional naval officers
Professional boat builders (including part-time specialists)
Dryd docks: permanent structures used during the construction and repair of vessels
Professional sailors, pilots, or navigators (including part-time specialists)
Professional boatmen, who earn a living ferrying passengers or goods over short distances

column3: Voyages undertaken out of sight of land
column4: Voyages undertaken out of sight of land
Canals built for navigation

column3: Mnemonic devices for recording traditions, events, etc.
column4: Traditions, events, etc., recorded by means of mnemonic devices (including writing, but excluding simple methods of recording elapsed time, events, or simple inventories)

Essentially phonetic system of writing
Scribes, secretaries, or clerks (other than priests)

column3: Schools for secular subjects or vocational training
column4: Schools for instruction in secular (i.e., nonreligious) subjects or for vocational training (including, e.g., school for brides)

column3: Literacy general among the upper classes
column4: Literacy general among the upper classes (not merely among scribes and priests)
Public primary schools
Secular professional schools (e.g., for the study of law, accounting, medicine, grammar)
Literature: speculative, esthetic, or historical writing as distinct from official records
Epic verse (excluding songs)

Philosophy: a system of beliefs about man’s place in the world and about human conduct based on independent speculation and representing a departure from the prevailing or previously established system of beliefs
Technical treatises or manuals (e.g., on medicine, pharmacy, divination, agriculture, metalworking)
Standardized weights and measures (excluding measurement with parts of the body, and similarly variable measurements)

Mathematics (beyond simple arithmetic)
Techniques of surveying and mensuration (including, e.g., plumb lines, knowledge of right angle, stretched cords, but excluding the swinging of circles by means of a cord)

column4: Calendrically fixed days of celebration or religious observance recurring annually

column3: Regular schedule of work and rest beyond daily routine
column4: Regular schedule of work and rest other than daily routine (e.g., one day off every five)
Musical instruments (excluding whistles)
Games of calculation
Team athletic contests in which there is coordination among the members of each side
Professional athletes (e.g., gladiators, ballplayers, acrobats)
Bards, minstrels, musicians, or storytellers, whose primary activity is to compose, play, or recite songs, poems, or stories
Professional dancers or musicians
Professional comic entertainers (e.g,, clowns, buffoons, jesters, dwarfs)
Troupes of professional actors
Fermented beverages brewed from cultivated plants

column3: Midwives, wet nurses, or foster nurses
column4: Midwives, wet nurses, or foster nurses who are regularly called upon and paid for their services
